snippet: Plains All American Pipeline had acknowledged the potential for oil to leak from the 24-inch, 10.6-mile-long pipeline west of Santa Barbara, but called the risk remote.
abstract: Spill response plan filed with California state regulators by Plains All American Pipeline, Texas company responsible for spilling up to 101,000 gallons of crude oil near Santa Barbara, had claimed rupture would be 'extremely unlikely' due to state-of the-art protections and monitoring; federal regulators endorsed plan in 2014 and are now investigating whether it was followed or if it was outdated; preliminary information suggests that breach was due to corrosion.
lead_paragraph: Plains All American Pipeline had acknowledged the potential for oil to leak from the 24-inch, 10.6-mile-long pipeline west of Santa Barbara, but called the risk remote.

headline.main: Firm in California Oil Spill Called a Rupture ‘Unlikely’
headline.print_headline: Firm in California Oil Spill Called a Rupture ‘Unlikely’
